summary: Linnaeus establishes a zoological classification system in which each animal is given a two-part name (binomial) consisting of a genus followed by a species within that genus. Similar species are grouped into genera, similar genera into orders, similar orders into classes, and similar classes into kingdoms. On page 33, Linnaeus lists distinguishing characteristics of elephants and classifies them as a single genus and species, Elephas maximus, in the order Bruta, the class Mammalia, and the kingdom Animalia.
title: Systema Naturæ Per Regna Tria Naturæ, Secundum Classes, Ordines, Genera, Species, Cum Characteribus, Differentiis, Synonymis, Locis.

notes: • Bottommost copy from Johann Friedrich Blumenbach – Online was owned by Blumenbach.
summary: Blumenbach recognizes two species of living elephants and describes them on pages 124–125. He gives each a distinct name, Elephas asiaticus for the Asian elephant and E. africanus for the African elephant, and places them in the order Belluae.

notes: • Published in year 6 of the French Republican calendar, which corresponds to 1798 as the calendar began on 1792 September 22 (Convention nationale, 1793).
references: Convention nationale. (1793). Calendrier de la République française. Paris: Imprimerie nationale.
summary: Cuvier recognizes two species of living elephants and describes them on pages 146–149. He uses Elephas indicus for the Asian elephant, names the African elephant E. capensis, and states that elephants warrant placement in a new, unnamed order.
title: Tableau Élémentaire de L'Histoire Naturelle des Animaux.
